segments.text: Morning everyone. Big day - foundation pour for the Maple Street project. Weather's holding, concrete trucks should be here at 7.
Forms are solid, rebar inspection passed yesterday. We're ready to go.
Pump truck's set up on the north side. We've got good access for the chutes.
Good. Remind me - how many yards are we pouring today?
280 yards. Should take about 6 hours with the crew we have.
And we've got the vibrators ready? Can't have any voids or cold joints in this foundation.
Got four vibrators charged and two backups. Plus the finishing crew knows to work it smooth as we go.
Perfect. Temperature's supposed to stay above 45 degrees all day, so curing shouldn't be an issue.
Yeah, we'll cover it tonight with blankets anyway. Better safe than sorry.
I like it. What about test cylinders? We need those for the engineer.
We'll pull six cylinders - three for 7-day break and three for 28-day. Inspector's coming at 9 to witness.
Excellent. Now, safety brief - this is high-risk work. Concrete burns are serious. Everyone wears long sleeves, gloves, and eye protection.
Already briefed the crew this morning. Everyone knows the protocol.
Good. And keep people away from the pump line. That thing's under serious pressure.
We've got barriers set up. Only pump operator and finishers allowed in the pour zone.
Perfect. Alright, I'll be here all morning supervising. Tony, you're running point on the pour itself. Mike, you handle logistics with the trucks.
Got it. First truck should be rolling in any minute now.
Then let's get our PPE on and make this happen. This is the foundation for a six-story building - we only get one shot at this.

environment.background_sounds: early morning, equipment idling, gravel crunching, distant traffic
